headline.main: DEMOCRATIC JUBILEE.; DEMONSTRATION AT METROPOLITAN HALL FIVE THOUSAND IN COUNCIL. ADDRESS TO THE DEMOCRACY. SPEECH OE COMMODORE STOCKTON. Addresses of Hon. Francis B. Cutting, Chas, W. Carrigan, and others. LETTERS FROM DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMEN. Letter from Edwis Croswell, Esq. Letter from Hon. John H. Weller, of California. Letter from Greene C. Bronson. Letter from Col. Hunt, of Charleston, S. C. Letter from John D. Fay. Letter from Beverly Tucker, Esq. DEMOCRATIC JUBILEE.

docs.lead_paragraph: The "Hard" section of the Democracy of New-York held a grand congratulatory meeting at Metropolitan Hall, last evening. The house was packed with an audience who were very enthusiastic, and the proceedings passed off in excellent harmony and order. During the afternoon, salutes were fired, and the Democracy rejoiced beforehand.
docs.snippet: The "Hard" section of the Democracy of New-York held a grand congratulatory meeting at Metropolitan Hall, last evening. The house was packed with an audience who were very enthusiastic, and the proceedings passed off in excellent harmony and order....

headline.main: Probable Murder of an Actress in New-Orleans, and Suicide of the Assassin.
BROOKLYN CITY.; Lectures and Lecturers. Books and Reading.

docs.lead_paragraph: LECTURE BY REV. DR. BETHUNE. The first of the course of nine Lectures was delivered Tuesday evening at the Brooklyn Athenaeum, by Rev. Dr. BETHUNE, upon Lectures and Lecturers. There was a very respectable audience in attendance. The speaker, after a few prefatory remarks, said: The work Lecture is often strangely warped from its original meaning.

headline.main: LETTER FROM JOHN MITCHEL.; His Preparations for Escaping.

docs.lead_paragraph: MY DEAR REILLY: I have now passed nearly five years in captivity to the English enemyfour years, eleven months, and fourteen days; for my days have gone by heavily, and I had time to count them. ,If ?? endure it any longer, I fear the iron will enter into my soul and corrode-I fear the virtue, that is to say, the pluck will have gone out of me.

headline.main: Amusements.; SOUTH AMERICA. Twenty-One Days Later from Rio and the Argentine Republic--Return of Mr. Schenck--Reception of Mr. Trousdale--Speeches of Don Pedro 11--The Brazilian Minister Expelled from Paraguay--Disappearance of Fever--Al Quiet at Montevideo--Markets, &c., &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. BOURCICAULT'S COMEDY.--We have had but few occasions of visiting Mr. BURTON'S establishment lately. The entertainments usually provided there are not of a character to reader our grief very poignant at this circumstance Mr. BURTON has stopped aside from his usual course in producing the "Fox Hunt; or, the Adventures of Don Quixote the Second." and hence we are called on again to speak of the Chambers-street place of amusement.

headline.main: LATEST INTELLIGENCE; By Telegraph to the New-York Daily Times. IMPORTANT FROM THE CAPITAL. The Contest for the Speakership--Disney Stock Looking Up--The Health of the President.

byline.original: Special Dispatch to the New-York Daily Times

headline.main: SOUTH AMERICA.; Later from Rio Janeiro--Speech of Don Pedro

docs.lead_paragraph: We have files of papers from Rio de Janeiro, to Sept. 25, inclusive. The latest dates at Rio were, Foreign---New-York, Aug. 15; Baltimore, Aug 12; New-Orleans, Aug. 9; California, July 16; Liverpool, Aug 25; Lisbon, Aug. 30; Havre, Aug. 22; Hamburg, Aug. 19. South American and Interior--Buenos Ayres, Sept. 2; Montevideo, Sept. 4; Val. paraiso, June 30; Pernambuco, Sept. 16, and Bahia, Sept. 20.

headline.main: BROOKLYN CITY.; The Poor of New-York. UNFORTUNATE ACCIDENT WHILE DEER-HUNTING--EXTRAORDINARY CASE OF ENDURANCE. JUVENILE MISSIONARY SOCIETY. CHARITABLE INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL FOR VAGRANT GIRLS. DEAN-STREET, BETWEEN WASHINGTON AND VANDERBILT-AVENUES. LECTURE ON ROBERT BURNS. ANOTHER EMBANKMENT ACCIDENT. LABORERS' STRIKE. CIRCUIT COURT. MORTALITY. A NEW BANKING INSTITUTION. BODY FOUND.

docs.lead_paragraph: He is the man, of course, who will fulfil the law to the letter, and obey the spirit of tile new rules and regulations laid down by the Commissioners for his government; a perusal of which has lately very much edified us. The model Policeman devotes his whole time and attention to the business of his department--he follows no other calling for Section 1 especially prohibits it.
